chapter_title: CHAPTER IX. OF THE PROFITS OF STOCK.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: The rise and fall in the profits of stock depend upon the same causes with the rise and fall in the wages of labour, the increasing or declining state of the wealth of the society; but those causes affect the one and the other very differently.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: PART II.—Of the Produce of Land, which sometimes does, and sometimes does not, afford Rent.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: Human food seems to be the only produce of land, which always and necessarily affords some rent to the landlord. Other sorts of produce sometimes may, and sometimes may not, according to different circumstances.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: PART I. Of the Motives for Establishing New Colonies.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: The interest which occasioned the first settlement of the different European colonies in America and the West Indies, was not altogether so plain and distinct as that which directed the establishment of those of ancient Greece and Rome.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: PART II. Causes of the Prosperity of New Colonies.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: The colony of a civilized nation which takes possession either of a waste country, or of one so thinly inhabited that the natives easily give place to the new settlers, advances more rapidly to wealth and greatness than any other human society.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: PART III. Of the Advantages which Europe has derived From the Discovery of America, and from that of a Passage to the East Indies by the Cape of Good Hope.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: Such are the advantages which the colonies of America have derived from the policy of Europe.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: CHAPTER VIII. CONCLUSION OF THE MERCANTILE SYSTEM.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: CHAPTER IX. OF THE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS, OR OF THOSE SYSTEMS OF POLITICAL ECONOMY WHICH REPRESENT THE PRODUCE OF LAND, AS EITHER THE SOLE OR THE PRINCIPAL SOURCE OF THE REVENUE AND WEALTH OF EVERY COUNTRY.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations

chapter_title: The agricultural systems of political economy will not require so long an explanation as that which I have thought it necessary to bestow upon the mercantile or commercial system.
author: Adam Smith
book_title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations
